Not Another Apocalypse

10/01/2013

Alex Slingsby looks back on ten apocalypses we've all survived, somehow.

Image by

By James Bithell

Once again humanity has survived yet another apocalypse. It's a shame we're not given more credit. Legend was that only cockroaches will survive the Apocalypse, yet we've survived more end-of-the-worlds than you might think, and they just keep coming. Unless it's Doctor Who jumping at our beck and call every time someone decides to declare that our untimely deaths are on the way, Doomsday-style, we must be doing something right. 1. The city is doomed: Most won't remember this, but the first-recorded apocalypse epiphany occurred in 634 BCE, when the Romans prophesised that 120 years after they had founded Rome, the city and life as they knew it would be gone. The Romans based this on the myth that 12 eagles had once appeared to Romulus, each representing ten years of Rome's lifespan. Rumour has it, however, that they made very little effort to leave the city and find a new one, and instead sat still and awaited their fate. Perhaps a couple of birds are not always credible sources. 2. The one with the Antichrist: Martin of Tours was the next bringer of the bad news. He predicted not only that the world end before 400, but that the Antichrist had already been born to a poor unsuspecting mother. He wrote that the Antichrist has been "firmly established already in his early years", and that he would "achieve supreme power" once puberty kicked in. Perhaps his child had simply had a particularly bad tantrum that day. 3. Noah's Ark: In 500, we had a trio of self-assured activists claiming the world was nearing its end: Hippolytus of Rome, Sextus Julius Africanus, and Irenaeus. All three claimed that Jesus would return in the year 500, with some believers making speculations based on the dimensions of Noah's Ark. Once again, most survived the year 500. 4. To be taken with a pinch of salt: Pope Innocent III made an allegation against Islam, claiming that 666 years after the rise of the Muslim faith, the world would end in 1284. Considering the conspicuous differences between the two faiths; it would have been wise for humanity to take this doomsday declaration with a pinch of salt. 5. When time was running out: Christopher Columbus sailed the mighty ocean, found America, and claimed it to be India. So if his navigational skills were anything to go by, I personally wouldn't have trusted his Judgement Day judgements in a million years, and yet the world did. Once he had established a general awareness of life across the pond, Columbus then proceeded to preach that there wasn't long left to discover whatever else was left. He claimed that the world had actually been created back in 5343 BCE, with a lifespan of no more than 7000 years, and that time was running out. 6. Joanna thinks she's pregnant: Joanna Southcott, a self-proclaimed prophet from Devon, claimed that she was pregnant with Christ, and that the due date was none other than Christmas Day 1814. The end was about nine months away, but apparently only for Southcott, who died on her due date, of an unknown illness and without child. 7. The musician: In 1969, Charles Manson, an American criminal and musician, became the leader of a quasi-commune known as the Manson Family in the 1960s. Manson declared that an apocalyptic race war would begin in 1969, helped along by the Tate-LaBianca murders carried out by members of the Manson Family. He was later sentenced to life imprisonment. There was no such apocalyptic race war, and once again, the world did not end. 8. The computer bug: This leads me to 2000, the year everybody raised their champagne glasses to welcome the new Millennium in, and then hid under the tables in a bid to escape the end-of-the-world that would undoubtedly emerge from the aftermath of a computer bug. Surely it would not have been unreasonable to suggest that if the world were to end at this stage in modern technology, it would have been caused by some computer bug a sixteen-year-old Antichrist has implanted in every major organisation's system, undetected by even the smartest of computer scientists, and ready to send humanity into a cyclone of despair, confusion, and anarchy, whereby society would cease to function without the aid of technology? This would not be unreasonable, despite the fact that for thousands of years, the world had managed to survive without computers. The aptly-named Y2K was supposed to cause worldwide catastrophes, which is arguably something the world is quite good at managing unassisted. The year 2000 passed by without an incident of the apocalyptic kind. 9. A change of heart: Harold Camping jumped on the already pretty heavy bandwagon in 2011, claiming that the Rapture would occur on 21st May, when God would judge us all, pick his favourite three per cent, and take them up to Heaven. The rest, it was believed, he would leave to fate and natural disasters, with the curtains coming to a close on 21st October. It is to be noted that Camping later revised his declaration, probably just after nothing happened on 21st May, and reaffirmed that the world would still end in October, whether we liked it or not. It didn't. 10. Money problems: Last year a man named Jose let us all in on a little secret of his - the world would end. The aptly named Jose Luis de Jesus blamed the end-of-the-world occurrence on our current governments. He claimed that the world's economies would fail, one by one, and that once this had properly ruined Christmas, Jose and his followers would develop the ability to fly and walk through walls. Fortunately, Jose and his companions didn't have to resort to this rather obscure form of emergency escape. Well after all that, we're all still alive, despite what has been thrown at us in recent centuries. We're either incredible at pretending to be cockroaches, or the prophets have to take blame for a couple of mild miscalculations. Photo credits in ascending order: Rameshng, Ken Zirkel and Tony Fischer Photography.
